The following archive contains microfiche-resolution imagery viewed through CSS approximation of a 1978 Bell & Howell Model 764 projection lens. Content has not been enhanced, sharpened, or made legible in any way. Prolonged viewing may cause: squinting, headache, existential reflection, and an unshakable feeling that you recognize someone in Frame 12. The operators of this archive accept no liability for ophthalmological, marital, or philosophical consequences.

Pre-Owned Microfiche Erotica

EST. 2007 — DAYTON, OHIO — CATALOG #PME-001 THROUGH #PME-4,612

In March of 2007 I found three shoeboxes under Gerald's workbench. They were labeled "TAX RECEIPTS 1974–1976," "DRILL BITS (METRIC)," and "CHURCH." They did not contain tax receipts, drill bits, or anything related to church. They contained 4,612 frames of microfiche. You can guess the rest.

I am Agnes Plumtree. I was a cataloger for the Dayton Public Library system for thirty-one years. I have organized periodicals, municipal records, and the entire Beavercreek Township zoning archive. I was not prepared for what Gerald had filed under "CHURCH," but I was, by professional instinct, prepared to catalog it. So I did. And then I put it online, because Gerald deserved that.1

BELL & HOWELL 764 — FRAME 1 OF 4,612
"We are all poorly archived."
CATALOG REF: PME-PERSONNEL-003 / GRIMSBY, B. Barnaby Grimsby served as volunteer archivist from 2009 to 2014. He personally re-graded 1,200 frames using a dust-particle methodology of his own design, delivered impassioned lectures on the narrative structure of Lot #2207, and one Tuesday in November simply did not come in. His Bell & Howell Model 552 was found running in the basement. The Naughty Nun collection (Lots #3301–3318) was gone. His reading glasses were on the table. The bulb was still warm. STATUS: MISSING — DO NOT RECALL

The Dust Jacket Grading Scale

OFFICIAL PME CONDITION ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL v3.1

VDF — Virtually Dust-Free

≤ 12 particles per cm²
Suspicious. Nobody kept these this clean on purpose. Possible evidence of care, which is worse.

LDP — Light Dust Present

13–40 particles per cm²
The honest grade. Somebody looked at this, felt something, and put it back in the box. Respectable.

HDA — Heavy Dust Accumulation

41–120 particles per cm²
Decades of neglect. The dust has its own ecosystem. Barnaby called these "seasoned." I let him.

AOD — Archivally Obscured by Dust

121–300 particles per cm²
You will need a magnifying glass and a willingness to be disappointed. Most of Gerald's collection falls here.

PT — Pharaoh's Tomb

> 300 particles per cm²
We assume something is here. The frame emits a faint smell of basement. One collector described it as "looking at a memory of a memory." He paid $40 for it.

Micro-Reviews by Macro-Minds

SELECTED CRITICAL ASSESSMENTS FROM OUR SUBSCRIBER BASE
"One encounters in Frame 47 of Lot #2207 what Sartre might have called the 'nausea of the half-visible' — a figure, possibly reclining, possibly standing, rendered by dust and time into pure ambiguity. The viewer is forced to project meaning onto grain. This is not pornography. This is the pornography of epistemology."
RE: Lot #2207 — "Untitled (Reclining?)" — Grade: HDA
Dr. Helen Ashworth, Comparative Literature, Univ. of Akron, Retired
"Foucault argued that the archive is never neutral. Lot #889 proves this with devastating clarity. The power dynamics between the archivist — presumably Gerald, that coward — and the archived subject are rendered literal by the physical degradation of the medium. Each dust particle is a tiny act of erasure. Gerald, you coward. The frame is Panopticism in miniature."
RE: Lot #889 — "Form 32B-Supplemental" — Grade: AOD
Prof. Martin Quelch, Critical Theory & Archival Studies, Oberlin College (Adjunct)
"I have spent eleven months with this frame. I have adjusted contrast, brightness, and my own expectations. I have consulted two optometrists and one psychic. The figure in the lower right is either holding a surveyor's transit or a dental mirror. I will not rest. I will not be reasonable about this. Mr. Fluffington — if that is his name — was a professional, and I intend to determine which profession."
RE: Lot #4409, Frame 12 — "Mr. Fluffington Incident" — Grade: PT
Diane Kowalski, Independent Researcher, Terre Haute, IN (self-funded)
